item.title: get_started_bk
item.dc:creator: iscdadm
item.content:encoded:
The content on this page are dedicated for people who have already applied for an account on MeSU servers, and have received a confirmation mail from the MeSU staff containing their username and password. If that is not your case yet, please consult the page How to apply to get information on your eligibity to use MeSU servers and to request for the creation of an account.

Content

  1. Login 1.1 - UNIX system 1.2 - Windows system
  2. File transfer 2.1 - Sample code 2.2 - File transfer
  3. Compilation 3.1 - Prepare the environment 3.2 - Compilation
  4. Set your job parameter 4.1 - Frontal nodes vs compute nodes 4.2 - The batch schedule 4.3 - PBS scripts
  5. Submit and monitor your job 5.1 - Submit your job 5.2 - Monitor your job status
  6. Resume

  7. 1 - Login

    1.1 - UNIX system

    In a terminal, execute the following command to login via ssh: [crayon lang="bash"] ssh your_username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr [/crayon] Type your password when prompted, and you should be connected to the MeSU servers.

    1.2- Windows system

    Connect via a ssh client (MobaXTerm, Putty) with the following informations:
    • server adress: mesu.dsi.upmc.fr
    • port: 22
    • username: your username
    • password: your password
    More details about the login procedure are available on the pages:
                • Remote login
                • Change your password
                • Graphical forwarding
                • Use ssh keys
     

    2 - Transfer files to MeSU servers

    2.1 - Sample code

    On your personal computer, download  and extract the zip archive containing sample codes: In the downloaded directory, you can find some sample codes demonstrating how to run different types of programs on MeSU servers. For this tutorial, we are going to test a simple OpenMP C program computing the value of PI in parallel (pi_openmp.c). Relevant parts of this code are displayed thereafter: [crayon lang="cpp"] ... #include <omp.h> int main(int argc, char* argv[]){ ... int i; #pragma omp parallel for reduction(+:sum) private(x) for (i=1;i<= nIterations; i++){ x = (i-0.5)*step; sum = sum + 4.0/(1.0+x*x); } pi = step * sum; ... printf("Number of threads = %i\n", omp_get_max_threads()); printf("Approximation of pi = %f\n", pi); printf("Computation time = %llu ms\n", t); ... [/crayon]

    2.2- File transfer

    Using the scp command (UNIX)
    From a terminal on your local computer, you can transfer the extracted directory to MeSU servers using the following command: [crayon lang="bash"] cd /path/to/your/downloads/directory scp -r wiki username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:~ [/crayon]
    Using a graphical client (all O.S.)
    On Windows, but also available on UNIX systems, different graphical applications use the sftp (Secure File Transfer Protocol) in a user-friendly environment, and can allow you to mount your MeSU workspace on your personal computer:
                • Filezilla can be used from the majority of O.S. and offers advanced file manipulation
                • Finder (MacOs), Nautilus (Ubuntu) and File explorer (Windows) have built-in tools to mount your MeSU workspace on your local computer
    More information on file transfer is available on the dedicated page.  

    3 - Compilation

    3.1 - Prepare the environment

    In order to be able to compile and run the code, we will need to tell the compiler (GCC) to enable OpenMP. To do so, the command line flag "-fopenmp" is usually used with gcc. However, for this example, we will use an OpenMP implementation optimized for the MeSU servers, called mpt. mpt is not activated by default on your session, and activating requires you to load a module, which grant you access to advanced libraries and softwares: [crayon lang="bash"] module load mpt [/crayon] More details on the use of modules can be found on the following pages:
                • Work with modules
                • Available modules

    3.2 - Compilation

    Now that the software environment is ready, you can compile the sample code: [crayon lang="bash"] cd openmp gcc pi_openmp.c -o pi_openmp -fopenmp ls [/crayon] Your program has been compiled, and an executable file called "pi_openmp" has therefore been created in the current directory.  

    4 - Set your job parameters

    4.1 - Frontal nodes vs compute nodes

    On a classical computer, you would have executed the program right after its compilation. However, MeSU servers have a special architecture, typical to High Performance Computing servers, which is fundamentally different than a typical computer:
    The compute nodes are distinct from the login node
    Put simply, the compute nodes, i.e the node of the servers where your jobs will run, are inaccessible to a direct login from the users. The only part of the servers you can directly access are the login nodes, also called frontal nodes. Those different types of nodes therefore have different usages:
                • frontal nodes: prototyping, developing and testing code - setting softwares parameters - preparing data ...
                • compute nodes: running the compiled code in parallel - executing long and CPU-intensive "production runs" ...
    You can find more informations on the architecture of MeSU servers on the MeSU architecture and Technical Specifications pages.

    4.2 - The batch scheduler

    To execute a job on the otherwise inaccessible compute nodes, PBS (a specific software called a Batch Scheduler) is installed and permanently running on the frontal nodes. The scheduler's role is to interface the frontal nodes with the compute nodes, in order to manage and optimize the distribution of jobs, request computing resources according to the user's needs (number of CPU cores, RAM memory, time of execution...), and prioritize resources requests so that a broad range of jobs can run simultaneously (i.e keeping enough resources to execute short jobs needing very few cores, delaying bigger jobs while guarantying their execution...). Using the PBS batch system is therefore mandatory to allow your jobs to run on compute nodes.

    4.3 - PBS scripts

    The interaction with PBS happens through script files (bash or python formats), which will be analyzed and executed by PBS. It is important to note that those scripts are executed on compute nodes, which memory and environment is cleaned after each run. Therefore, these scripts will contain commands to load modules, set environment variables, copy executables and parameter files, write log files back to the frontal nodes... The script used in this walkthrough is "script_openmp.sh": [crayon lang="bash"] #!/bin/bash # #PBS -l select=1:ncpus=16 #PBS -l walltime=04:00:00 #PBS -N pi_openmp #PBS -j oe #Load modules . /usr/share/modules/init/sh module load mpt/2.11 #Copy the executable to the temporary directory cp $PBS_O_WORKDIR/pi_openmp . #Execute omplace -nt 16 ./pi_openmp > log.txt #Transfer log cp log.txt $PBS_O_WORKDIR [/crayon] Note that in the present script, executed on the compute nodes, the active directory ( . ) is located on the compute nodes, while the $PBS_O_WORKDIR environment variable designs the directory from which the job was submitted, on the frontal nodes. More information on PBS scripts can be found on the following pages:
                • PBS script syntax
                • PBS scripts examples
     

    5 - Submit and monitor your job

    5.1 - Submit your job

    To submit your job e.g on MeSU alpha (SGI UV2000), type in a command prompt: [crayon lang="bash"] qsub -q quv pi_serial.sh [/crayon] In the absence of errors, this command should output a line containing a 6 digits number: your job identifier, later referred to as job_id. This number will help you check and monitor the execution of your job with a few simple commands.

    5.2 - Monitor your job status

    The command qstat allows to see the status of the queues and queued jobs on MeSU servers. In a command prompt, you can therefore type the following command: [crayon lang="bash"] qstat [/crayon] If your job is currently queued, you should see it appear in the last lines of the result. However, the current servers status and load might prevent your job from running until enough resources are available. It is possible that the job has already been processed. If you do not see it after issuing the qstat command (and the previous "qsub" command was successful), a file ending in .o****** (example: pi_serial.o175462) should have been created. You can be set on the success or failure of your job by opening this file:
                • Hopefully, your job has successfully been processed. The file should then be empty, meaning that everything went as expected
                • If, for whatever reason, the job failed, the error stream should be present in this file, giving more information on the reason of the crash (system failure, segmentation fault, bad syntax...)
    To get more information about the resources used by your job (total time, cpu time, memory usage, exit code, number of nodes and cores...), you can type the following command in a command prompt: [crayon lang="bash"] qstat -fx job_id [/crayon] Finally, a file log.txt should be available in the current directory. This file contains the output generated by the pi_serial executable, i.e. the time spent computing and the estimated value of pi.

    6 - Résumé

    Executing a code from sources

    A typical workflow to execute a program from its source code could therefore be:
                1. Transfer source files from your personal computer to the frontal nodes, or download them from web archives
                2. Compile the code into an executable in test mode or debug mode on one of the frontal nodes (assigned when logging in)
                3. Test the code in debug or test mode (i.e on a small set of dummy data, with verbosity to its maximum level or limited to one core)
                4. If everything runs smoothly and no error appears, compile the code in release mode (i.e with optimizations turned on)
                5. Create the PBS script (or work from a template) to request resources and load modules, copy files and executables to the compute nodes, specify the executable arguments...
                6. Submit the job to PBS via qsub

    Running a software available on MeSU servers

    Running a pre-installed software would follow a different workflow:
          1. Prepare the input data and parameters files on the frontal nodes
          2. Optionnaly load the module containing the desired software and make a debug run on the frontal nodes to ensure that parameters and variables are set correctly
          3. Create the PBS script (or work from a template) to load the modules containing the target software, set environment variables, copy files to the compute nodes, specify the software options and execute the software...
          4. Submit the job to PBS via qsub

item.content:encoded:
HPCaVe Organizational Chart

HPCaVe Staff
If you need to contact staff about issues you have with HPC resources or with any question about user services, the best way to contact us is by email at mesu@upmc.fr. All staff members read these emails and can respond in the event a particular staff member is absent. You may also call the main phone number xx xx xx xx between 9am-5pm.

item.title: Resources
item.dc:creator: iscdadm
item.content:encoded:
MeSU-alpha

MeSU-alpha is a SMP server, equipped with 1024 cores and 16Tb. of shared memory.

MeSU-alpha's specificity being its large quantity of accessible RAM, users should mainly use this server for memory-intensive jobs and programs (that need to load more than 128Gb of data in RAM at runtime), or codes based on threads or OpenMP API.

More info

MeSU-beta

MeSU-beta is a distributed cluster, equipped with a total of 3012 cores.

MeSU-beta is a high performance distributed cluster, which will be the preferred architecture for users who wish to use highly scalable parallel programs or codes, based on standards such as MPI.

More info

Visualization room

HPCaVe also grants to its users access to a visualization room located on the Jussieu campus, equipped with a 6x2.2m stereoscopic projection screen connected to a linux workstation. Directly connected on HPCaVe data directories, the visualization room is a perfect environment for researchers to gather and analyse/visualize their computation results. Please, contact us for more information or to book a session in the visualization room.

More info

item.title: Accounts and Access
item.dc:creator: iscdadm
item.content:encoded:
HP-CaVe account

HP-CaVe Platform provides services to the Sorbonne Université research community, academic HPC users, and industry partners throughout a variety of resources such as high performance computing, visualization, data analysis. All persons using this platform resources must read and accept the HPCaVe Policy, and the UPMC IT policy. The use of HP-CaVe ressources are allocated differently to the users depending on whether they are UPMC-Sorbonne Université or from exterior organizations including private sector:
  • For UPMC-Sorbonne Université members , accounts are valid for one year. The access to computing resources are :
    • granted and free of charge for up to 35.000h / year, more resources can painlessly be provided with sufficient scientific motivation. A warning message will be sent when quota exceeded 80%
    • There is no backups for your data
  • For exterior organizations, accounts are valid for one year. Access to computing resources is made possible either on a pay-per-hour policy, or on research contracts. There is no backups for your data. For more information,please refer to the HPCaVe  Pricing Table or contact us at mesu@upmc.fr.

Who can apply for an account ?

HP-CaVe accounts are available for :
  • All UPMC and Sorbonne Université faculty, research staff, and graduate students with the approval of their faculty advisor, for the purpose of research.
  • Laboratory or research team working on multiple projects requiring such resources.
  • Companies, academic/non-academic researchers and engineers are welcome to an account also.
For any questions about qualifying for a HP-CaVe account, please contact the HPCaVe Service Desk.

How to open an account ?

Before applying for an HP-CaVe account, it is important for you to consider the following points:
  • Users can subscribe at any time of the year.
  • Accounts are granted to UPMC users for one full year max
  • CPU quotas are reset every year
  • HPCaVe does not provide any back up for your data
  • By using HPCaVe services, you commit to abide the HPCaVe usage policies and UPMC I.T. policies
To apply for a HP-CaVe account you will need to print, fulfill and scan this application form and send it back by e-mail to HPCaVe Service Desk (mesu@upmc.fr) or via the following form. Please note that a 48 hours examination of your request is needed to give you an answer.
[contact-form-7 id="1318" title="Application form"]

item.title: login
item.dc:creator: iscdadm
item.content:encoded:
Remote login

The remote login to MeSU servers is made through the ssh (Secure Shell) protocol, which allows a secure connection and reduces the risk of data corruption or fraudulent attack. Depending on your operating system, different methods are available to login on the servers.

UNIX (Linux / MacOs)

Open a terminal

To connect from UNIX systems (Linux or MacOS), the preferred method is to use a CLI (Command Line Interface), also known as a Terminal or a Console.
  • For MacOs Users, the CLI is available from the finder under Applications -> Utilities -> Terminal, or from the launchpad by searching "Terminal".
  • Different versions of Linux will use different CLIs, usually called "Terminal", and often located in the accessories menu panels.

Login with ssh

After the creation of your account on MeSU servers, you should have received an e-mail containing your credentials.
  1. From the terminal, and in order to login to MeSU servers, you should enter the following command by replacing username with your username: [crayon lang="bash"] ssh username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr [/crayon]
  2. The first time you login, your CLI application could warn you that you are trying to connect to an unknown host. You can safely continue the login process by typing "Y".
  3. The CLI will then prompt you for your password, which you should have received along your identifier. Type it carefully, as the characters you enter will not appear on your screen, and press Return to continue.
  4. On login success, a welcome message should appear, providing you with various informations about the system status, planned maintennce interventions or other important messages.
Bravo, you are now logged in!

Windows

Download a ssh client

Windows Operating System does not include a built-in ssh tool. You will therefore need to install one of the following ssh clients on your computer in order to login. If you have already used such a software, please use any ssh client you are already familiar with. Otherwise, we recommend MobaXTerm which is more user-friendly that most of its counterparts. Lots of other options are of course available (Putty, CigWin, Kitty, ...), but the login process will be very similar to the one demonstrated below with MobaXTerm.

Connect from (i.e.) MobaXTerm

item.title: Eligibility
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded: All faculty and research staff (including PhDs) at SU are eligible for a MeSU account Requests for accounts by research associates not affiliated with a SU Member Institution will be handled on a case by case basis Funding is not necessary to compute Further information can be found on the web site: http://iscd.upmc.fr/expertise/mesu Imminent upgrades may introduce changes

item.title: Privacy and security
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded: HPC systems are often under attack by would-be intruders Your data and research may be threatened by intruders Don’t let intruders in Keep your password or key passphrase safe Choose a strong password Keep the software on your laptops/PC up to date Don’t share account (forbidden by policies) Network traffic monitored (DSI)

item.title: Quotas and backups
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
Backup

There is currently no backups on MeSU In the (near) future, home directories (/home/userid) will be backed up, but: Be careful when deleting, backups are not an undelete Restoration depends on: File has existed long enough to be backed up The last valid version existing in the current backup Restoration is requested ASAP from loss of data Work/scratch files will not be backed up

Disk quotas

Do not let your job write output to your work directory Aim to stay under the limit A warning message will be sent when quota is exceeded

item.title: File transfer
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
Contents

  • 1 Transferring files to/from HPC systems
    • 1.1 Using sftp
    • 1.2 Using SSH Secure File Transfer
    • 1.3 Using scp
    • 1.4 Download from internet to MeSU

Transferring files to/from HPC systems

Users can transfer data files between their local machines and the HPC systems in several ways
  • using a ftp with explicit SSL encryption
  • via a secure copy scp: user must have scp on the local machine and a connection to the UPMC campus network. A scp program is part of recent releases of Unix-based systems (Linux and Apple OS X).
  • a SSH secure file transfer software (via the command ssh) : user must have SSH on the local machine and a connection to the UPMC campus network. A SSH Secure File Transfer Utility is available for Windows at this address.

Using sftp

Users are encouraged to use FTP with explicit SSL encryption for file transfer. In a terminal type: 
sftp mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr
Password:  Connected to mesu.dsi.upmc.fr. sftp>
You can navigate through the remote system's file hierarchy using a number of commands that function similarly to their shell counterparts. 
pwd cd subdirectory
You can print the local directory with the command 
lpwd
Local working directory: /Users/demouser
If you would like to download files from MeSU, issue the following command: 
 get mesufile
You can copy the remote file to a different name by specifying the name afterwards: 
 get mesufile newlocalfile
Transferring files to MeSU is just as easily accomplished by using the appropriately named put command: 
 put localfile
and to copy a local directory, you can issue: 
 put -r subdirectory
To return to the local session type 
 exit

Using SSH Secure File Transfer

Users need to start the Secure File Transfer application and open a connection to host mesu.dsi.upmc.fr and enter their password when prompted. Once the connection is established, you can upload or download files.

Using scp

Open a terminal in your local machine. Change to the directory where the files are located in your local machine (cd directory_containing_data_files). At the command prompt type: 
 scp filename userLDAP@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/
where filename is the name of the file to be transferred, userLDAP is your login name, and subdirectory is the subdirectory in MeSU home directory to which files are being transferred. You will then be asked to enter the password. (Note: userLDAP@ can be omitted if your login name on MeSU is the same as on your local machine). Using the scp secure copy command, you can transfer multiple files from your local machine to your home directory on MeSU. 
 scp file1 file2 file3 userLDAP@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/
Wildcards can also be used for multiple file transfer (e.g. all files with .txt extension): 
 scp *.txt userLDAP@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr:~subdirectory/
To transfer files from MeSU to your local machine, from your local machine, issue the command: 
 scp userLDAP@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/filename .
The transferred file will be written in the current local directory. (Note: userLDAP@ can be omitted if your login name on MeSU is the same as on your local machine). Wildcards can also be used for multiple file transfer (e.g. all files with .txt extension): 
 scp userLDAP@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/\*.txt  .
It is also possible to transfer a whole directory at once using the command: 
 scp -r local_subdirectory/ userLDAP@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/

Download from internet to MeSU

The following example shows how to download FastaX software from internet directly to the cluster 
 wget https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/archive/master.zip

item.title: softwares
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
Softwares

Multiple softwares and tools analysis which can complete your work environment are available on HPCaVe platform. A standard Linux distribution is installed on scratchalpha and scratchbeta, along with standard tools used for development which are available by default. The other available packages (compilers, parallel libraries...), described on tables below need to be loaded before using them. However here are some useful commands you need to know before :
  • List all available modules
module avail
 
  • Load a module
module load modules_names
Example: 
module load intel-mpi/4.0.3.008 intel-compilers-15/15.0.0.090
 
  • List loaded modules
module list
Example: 
module list
Currently Loaded Module files:  
1) intel-mpi/4.0.3.008             3) intel-fc-15/15.0.0.090  2) intel-cc-15/15.0.0.090          4) intel-compilers-15/15.0.0.090

  • Unload a module from your environment
module unload module_name

  • Unload all modules from your environment
module purge

  • Print the content of a module
module display module_name
Example: 
module display module_name
-------------------------------------------------------------------/opt/dev/modulefiles/-------------------------------------------------------------------
intel-compilers-15/15.0.0.090:
module           load intel-cc-15/15.0.0.090 
module           load intel-fc-15/15.0.0.090

 

Softwares Tables

item.title: Compilation
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
In this section, examples of compilation and execution are given.

Compilers

GNU (gcc, g++, gfortran) Intel (icc, icpc, ifort)

Contents

  • 1 OPENMP with gcc / gfortran
  • 2 OPENMP with icc / ifort
  • 3 Hybrid OPENMP / SGIMPT with gcc & gfortran
  • 4 Hybrid OPENMP / SGIMPT with icc & ifort
  • 5 Hybrid OPENMP / SGIMPT compiled with mpiicc & mpiifort

OPENMP with gcc / gfortran

# Compiling pic.c with gcc  
    gcc -o pic_g.o -c pic.c -O3 -fopenmp

#Linking pic_g.o with gcc  
    gcc -o pic_g pic_g.o -O3 -fopenmp  -lm

# Compiling and Linking pif.F with gfortran  
    gfortran -o pif_g pif.F -O3 -fopenmp   
    export OMP_NUM_THREADS=4

# Execution with dplace  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p dplace ./pic_g 1234567890   
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p dplace ./pif_g -r 1234567890

# Execution with omplace  
    module load mpt  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p omplace -tm open64 ./pic_g 1234567890  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p omplace -tm open64 ./pif_g -r 1234567890

OPENMP with icc / ifort

  
module load intel-cc-12/12.1.0.233 
      
# Compiling pic.c with icc  
    icc -o pic_i.o -c pic.c -O3 -openmp 

# Linking pic.c with icc  
    icc -o pic_i pic_i.o -O3 -openmp  

# Compiling & Linking pif.F with ifort  
    module load intel-fc-12/12.1.0.233  ifort -o pif_i pif.F -O3 -openmp    
    export OMP_NUM_THREADS=8

#Execution with dplace  
    module load intel-compilers-12/12.1.0.233  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p dplace -x 2 ./pic_i 12345678900   
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p dplace -x 2 ./pif_i -r 12345678900 

#Execution with omplace  
    module load intel-compilers-12/12.1.0.233 mpt   
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p omplace  ./pic_i 12345678900  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p omplace  ./pif_i -r 12345678900

Hybrid OPENMP / SGIMPT with gcc & gfortran

module load mpt
# Compiling mpiomp.c with gcc  
    gcc -o mpiomp_gs.o -c mpiomp.c -O3 -fopenmp

# Linking mpiomp_gs.o with gcc  
    gcc -o mpiomp_gs mpiomp_gs.o -O3 -fopenmp  -lmpi  
    export OMP_NUM_THREADS=8

# Execution with MPI_OPENMP_INTEROP  
    MPI_OPENMP_INTEROP=1 time -p mpirun -np 4 ./mpiomp_gs 42345678900 ;

# Execution with omplace  
    module load  mpt  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p mpirun -np 4 omplace -tm open64 ./mpiomp_gs  42345678900

Hybrid OPENMP / SGIMPT with icc & ifort

module load mpt

# Compiling mpiomp.c with icc 
    icc -o mpiomp_is.o -c mpiomp.c -O3 -openmp
# Linking mpiomp_gs.o with gcc  
    icc -o mpiomp_is mpiomp_is.o -O3 -openmp   -lmpi  
    export OMP_NUM_THREADS=8

# Execution with MPI_OPENMP_INTEROP  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled MPI_OPENMP_INTEROP=1 time -p mpirun -np 4 ./mpiomp_is 42345678900 ;

# Execution with omplace  
    module load  mpt  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p mpirun -np 4 omplace            ./mpiomp_is 42345678900

Hybrid OPENMP / SGIMPT compiled with mpiicc & mpiifort

module load intel-cc-12/12.1.0.233 intel-mpi/4.1.0.024
# Compiling mpiomp.c with mpiicc  
    mpiicc -o mpiomp_ii.o -c mpiomp.c -O3 -openmp 

# Linking mpiomp_gs.o with mpiicc 
    mpiicc -o mpiomp_ii mpiomp_ii.o -O3 -openmp  
    export OMP_NUM_THREADS=8  
    module purge  
    module load intel-cc-12/12.1.0.233 mpt perfboost

# Execution with MPI_OPENMP_INTEROP and perfboost  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled MPI_OPENMP_INTEROP=1 time -p mpirun -np 4 perfboost -impi ./mpiomp_ii  42345678900


# Execution with omplace and perfboost  
    KMP_AFFINITY=disabled time -p mpirun -np 4 perfboost -impi omplace ./mpiomp_ii  42345678900

item.title: PBS scripts
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
Creating a PBS script

#!/bin/bash
#

#PBS -l select=1:ncpus=64
#PBS -l select=8:ncpus=8
#PBS -l select=3:ncpus=24
#PBS -l select=3:ncpus=24:mpiprocs=24

#PBS -l walltime=4:00:00
#PBS -N test
#PBS -j oe 

. /usr/share/modules/init/sh
module load module1
module load module2

# go to directory in which the job_script_file reside
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR
time -p test_executable > log.txt

item.title: Job submission
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
The queueing system on MeSU-alpha (SGI UV 2000, 1024 cores, shared memory) and MeSU-beta (SGI ICE-XA, 2020 cores, distributed cluster) is PBS (Portable Batch System). You can run a job on these systems with a command prompt for simple serial jobs (not recommended) or by setting up a PBS script that defines the commands and resources used for the job (recommended option). A PBS script is a simple text file that can be created using any text editor (Emacs, vi, nedit, pico...).

Batch queue on SGI systems

MeSU-alpha (SGI UV2000)

The following queues are available on MeSU-alpha: f16c, f32c, f48c, f64c where the number xx in fxxc denotes the number of cores you may use. More cores may be requested through specific queues:np_f64c, np_128c, np_256c at night, p_128c at day.These queues are only available a few days per year, on request (HPC challenges).

MeSU-beta (SGI ICE XA)

The following queues are available day and night on MeSU-beta (SGI ICE-XA):f96c, f336c, f672cNote: For very specific purposes (HPC challenges), a queue full will be opened once or twice a year (users will be notified by email). On this queue, programs will be able to use all the ressources available on the systems. Users interested to get access to this feature should contact the platform manager in advance.For more informations about the queues, please visit the Available queues page.

Submitting a serial test job (without PBS)

In all the sample scripts, the working_directory refers to your working directory.Users are supposed to run jobs via PBS only. Nonetheless, for testing purposes, it may be useful to submit a job directly on the front-end server. Here is a sample of the submission of a serial job, where firstjob is an executable previously compiled: 
 
#!/bin/bash 
cd working_directory 
./firstjob < data_input > data_output
Entering a standard input file (data_input) and standard output file (data_output) is only necessary if your program requires input from standard input and if it outputs data to standard output. It is possible to specify the working_directory as follows: 
 
#!/bin/bash 
cd ${HOME}/my_project

Editing a PBS script

By using the PBS queue manager, users are allowed to use MeSU-alpha and MeSU-beta computing servers. To set the parameters for the job, users can create a control file that contains all the commands to be executed. Typically, this is done in the form of a PBS script, created according to the following example: 
 
#!/bin/bash 
#PBS -l select=1:ncpus=64 
#PBS -l walltime=4:00:00 
#PBS -N test 
#PBS -j oe  
# load modules 
. /usr/share/modules/init/sh 
module load intel-fc-13/13.0.1.117 
module load mpt 
# change to the directory where program job_script_file is located 
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR 
time -p test_executable
  • The first line identifies which shell will be used for the job. Here bash is used but csh or other valid shells would also work.
  • The second line specifies the number of nodes and processors desired for this job. Here, one node with 64 cpus is being requested. This will only work on MeSU-alpha (UV 2000) as MeSU-beta (ICE-XA) does not have 64-cpus on its nodes.
  • The third line states how much wall-clock time is being requested. In this example 4 hours of wall time have been requested.
  • The fourth and fifth line specify the name of the job, as well as the fact that errors and outputs files should be merged.
  • The next paragraph concerns the module initializations, about which informations can be found on Available modules and Modules Initialization pages.
  • The final paragraph is the "execution part" of your job. It defines the execution commands, log saves, monitoring... of the job you wish to run.
  • Please note that the time command included in the sample script above is optional (this command measures the amount of time it takes to run an executable).
For more script examples, please visit the Advanced job submission page.

Submitting a PBS script

The last step to submit a job is to run the qsub command after having the edition of a PBS script according to the resources needed. In order to submit a job associated with a PBS script called myScript.sh, type in the command prompt: 
qsub myScript.sh
If not stated otherwise, your job will then be executed on MeSU-beta (SGI ICE XA).That is why it is highly recommended to specify the target architecture with the -q option: 
qsub -q qice myScript.sh (To run on MeSU-beta)
qsub -q quv  myScript.sh (To run on MeSU-alpha)
Using this option will allow you to avoid ambiguities when submitting jobs adapted to one of the MeSU servers. Finally, it might be useful to know that the options given in the header part of your PBS scripts (such as "-l select=4:ncpus=24") can also be passed as options to the qsub command. For example: 
qsub -q qice -l select=4:ncpus=24 myScript.sh
This command will output a 6-digits number, corresponding to your job ID, and useful for further monitoring and debugging. More information about monitoring your job can be found on Advanced job submission page.        

Advanced job submission

Contents

  • 1 Job submission
  • 2 Optimal Placement Grouping (MeSU-alpha only)
  • 3 Script Examples
    • 3.1 1 chunk of 64 CPUs (UV2000 only)
    • 3.2 8 chuncks of 8 CPUs (UV2000 & ICE XA)
    • 3.3 3 chuncks of 24 CPUs (ICE XA only)
    • 3.4 3 chuncks of 24 cpus for full MPI use (ICE XA only)
    • 3.5 Job Array (UV 2000)

Job submission

MeSU alpha and MeSU beta use PBS as their queue manager. The "qsub" command allows users to specify a script used by PBS in order to prioritize and manage the execution of their jobs. According to the header of the script sent that way, PBS will route the job on the right machine and the right queue:
  • MeSU alpha (SGI UV 2000, 1024 cores, shared memory)
  • MeSU beta (SGI ICE XA, 2020 cores, distributed cluster)
Use the command : qsub -q [ qice | quv ] job_script_file
Don't forget the -q option, which will route your job on the machine according to your CPUs and cores distribution requirement!
Some examples targeting the different systems are given below.

Optimal Placement Grouping (MeSU-alpha only)

  
8 cores       
#PBS -l place=excl:group=socket 16 cores       
#PBS -l place=excl:group=board 32 cores       
#PBS -l place=excl:group=boardpair 64 cores       
#PBS -l place=excl:group=iruhalf128 cores       
#PBS -l place=excl:group=iru512 cores       
#PBS -l place=excl:group=rack

Script Examples

1 chunk of 64 CPUs (UV2000 only)

The following script will only work on UV2000 because there no are no 64 cpus on an ICEXA node. 
#!/bin/bash
#
#PBS -l select=1:ncpus=64
#PBS -l walltime=4:00:00
#PBS -N test
#PBS -j oe 

# load modules
. /usr/share/modules/init/sh
module load intel-fc-13/13.0.1.117
module load mpt

# go to directory in which the job_script_file reside
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR
time -p test_executable
Submission on UV 
qsub -q quv job_script_file
Submission on ICE XA possible but will never run

8 chuncks of 8 CPUs (UV2000 & ICE XA)

The following job will work on UV2000 and ICE XA. 
#!/bin/bash
#
#PBS -l select=8:ncpus=8
#PBS -l walltime=4:00:00
#PBS -N test
#PBS -j oe 
# load modules
. /usr/share/modules/init/sh
module load intel-fc-13/13.0.1.117
module load mpt
# go to directory in which the job_script_file reside
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR
time -p test_executable
Submission on UV 
qsub -q quv job_script_file
-> will go to queue f64c on UV2000 -> will reserve 8 UV vnodes Submission on ICE XA 
qsub -q qice job_script_file
-> will go on queue f96c on ICE XA -> will reserve 3 nodes -> will assign 3 , 3 , 2 vnodes (for MPI usage) 
cat $PBS_NODEFILE

r1i0n0-ib0
r1i0n0-ib0
r1i0n0-ib0
r1i0n1-ib0
r1i0n1-ib0
r1i0n1-ib0
r1i0n10-ib0
r1i0n10-ib0

pbsn | grep exclu

r1i0n0-ib0	job-exclusive	131926668kb	24
r1i0n1-ib0	job-exclusive	131926668kb	24
r1i0n10-ib0	job-exclusive	131926668kb	24

qstat -n 175032
mesu0: 
                                                              Req'd  Req'd  Elap
Job ID          Username   Queue    Jobname    SessID NDS TSK Memory Time  S Time    --------------- -------- -------- ---------- ------ --- --- ------ ----- - -----
175032.mesu0    frey     f96c       STDIN    20479   8  64    --   01:00 R 00:00   r1i0n0-ib0/0*8+r1i0n0-ib0/1*8+r1i0n0-ib0/2*8+r1i0n1-ib0/0*8+r1i0n1-ib0/1*8   +r1i0n1-ib0/2*8+r1i0n10-ib0/0*8+r1i0n10-ib0/1*8

3 chuncks of 24 CPUs (ICE XA only)

The following job will work only on ICE XA. 
#!/bin/bash
#
#PBS -l select=3:ncpus=24
#PBS -l walltime=4:00:00
#PBS -N test#PBS -j oe 
# load modules
. /usr/share/modules/init/sh
module load intel-fc-13/13.0.1.117module load mpt

# go to directory in which the job_script_file reside
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR
time -p test_executable
Submission on UV 
qsub -q quv job_script_file
-> will never run Submission on ICE XA 
qsub -q qice job_script_file
-> will go on queue f96c on ICE XA -> will reserve 3 nodes -> will assign 1, 1, 1 vnode (for MPI use) 
cat $PBS_NODEFILE

r1i0n0-ib0
r1i0n1-ib0
r1i0n10-ib0

pbsn | grep exclu

r1i0n0-ib0	job-exclusive	131926668kb	24
r1i0n1-ib0	job-exclusive	131926668kb	24
r1i0n10-ib0	job-exclusive	131926668kb	24 

qstat -n 175031
mesu0:
                                                             Req'd  Req'd   Elap
Job ID          Username Queue    Jobname    SessID NDS TSK  Memory Time  S Time--------------- -------- -------- ---------- ------ --- --- ------ ----- - -----
175031.mesu0    frey     f96c     STDIN       20424   3  72    --   01:00 R 00:28   r1i0n0-ib0/0*24+r1i0n1-ib0/0*24+r1i0n10-ib0/0*24

3 chuncks of 24 cpus for full MPI use (ICE XA only)

The following job will work only on ICE XA. 
#!/bin/bash
#
#PBS -l select=3:ncpus=24:mpiprocs=24
#PBS -l walltime=4:00:00#PBS -N test
#PBS -j oe 
# load modules
. /usr/share/modules/init/sh
module load intel-fc-13/13.0.1.117
module load mpt

# go to directory in which the job_script_file reside
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR
time -p test_executable
Submission on UV 
qsub -q quv job_script_file
-> will never run Submission on ICE XA 
qsub -q qice job_script_file
-> will go on queue f96c on ICE XA -> will reserve 3 nodes -> with assign 24, 24, 24 vnode (for MPI use) 
cat $PBS_NODEFILE

qstat -n 175033

mesu0:     
                                                        
                                                            Req'd  Req'd   Elap
Job ID          Username Queue    Jobname    SessID NDS TSK Memory Time  S Time                         --------------- -------- -------- ------

175033.mesu0     frey     f96c     STDIN     20522   3  72    --   01:00 R 00:00   r1i0n0-ib0/0*24+r1i0n1-ib0/0*24+r1i0n10-ib0/0*24

Job Array (UV 2000)

A PBS Job Array is submitted with : 
qsub -J range jobarray_script_file

-J range: Declares  that  this  job  is an array job.  
Sets job's array attribute to TRUE.
The argument <b>range</b> identifies the integers greater than or equal to zero that are associated with the sub-jobs  of  the array. 
Range is specified in the form X-Y[:Z]  where X is the first index, Y is the upper bound on the indices and Z is the stepping factor.
For example,  2-7: 2 will produce indices of 2, 4, and 6. 
If Z is not specified, it is taken to be 1.
When the PBS starts the following environment variable are available inside the script: PBS_ARRAY_ID PBS_ARRAY_INDEX PBS_JOBID The variable PBS_ARRAY_INDEX can serve as a reference number to characterize different input files. Example : 
PBS_ARRAY_INDEX=11
PBS_ARRAY_ID=8273[].mesu0
PBS_JOBID=8273[11].mesu0
# ls input.11 input.12 input.13 input.14

#!/bin/bash
#
#PBS -l select=1:ncpus=64
#PBS -l walltime=4:00:00
#PBS -N test#PBS -j oe 
#PBS -J 11-14
# load modules
. /usr/share/modules/init/sh
module load intel-fc-13/13.0.1.117
module load mpt/2.07 


# go to directory in which the job_script_file reside
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR
time -p test_executable <input.$PBS_ARRAY_INDEX
qsub -q quv job_array_script_file

item.title: Job monitoring
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
Job monitoring

Global monitoring

qstat
qstat -u userName
qstat -T

Specific job monitoring

qstat -f job_id
tracejob job_id
nodelist job_id
nodedist $(nodelist job_id)
nodeinfo

Job array monitoring

qstat -tr
 

Advanced job monitoring

Multiple commands are useful to monitor the progress of your jobs, depending on the level of details needed.

Contents

  • 1 General jobs monitoring (qstat)
    • 1.1 Jobs Statuses
    • 1.2 Jobs with job array
    • 1.3 Other qstat options
  • 2 Specific Job monitoring
    • 2.1 Get your job ID
    • 2.2 Information about a submitted job
    • 2.3 Information about a finished job
    • 2.4 PBS log messages
    • 2.5 Computing nodes information

General jobs monitoring (qstat)

The most important command to remember is qstat, which displays the past and current jobs execution statuses.

Jobs Statuses

Use the command : qstat to obtain the job's status. 
qstat

mesu0:

Job id            Name             User              Time Use S Queue
----------------  ---------------- ----------------  -------- - -----
175702.mesu0      hello            root                     0 Q f96c
...                      
176289.mesu0      test             ducher            196:00:0 R f96c            
176290.mesu0      test             ducher            192:57:2 R f96c

Jobs with job array

qstat -tr

mesu0: 
                                                            Req'd  Req'd   Elap
Job ID          Username Queue    Jobname    SessID NDS TSK Memory Time  S Time
--------------- -------- -------- ---------- ------ --- --- ------ ----- - -----
139463.mesu0    creazzo  np_f64c  methane     84342   1  32  991gb 12:00 R 00:46
139647.mesu0    dagrada  np_f64c  FeSe_test  114566   1  64  991gb 05:00 R 00:42
...
139768.mesu0    tournier f64c     inverse    699497   1  64  480gb 04:00 R 01:36
139817.mesu0    navarrot f16c     LETKF      377552   1   4  247gb 00:45 R 00:00

Other qstat options

List all jobs from a specific user: 
qstat -u loginLDAP
Get estimated start time: 
qstat -T
More information on qstat can be found using the manual : man qstat

Specific Job monitoring

Get your job ID

The main information to understand a job behaviour is its job id, an unique 6 digits number used by PBS and characterizing your job. Use the command qstat to get this value, hereafter referred to as job_id.

Information about a submitted job

qstat -f job_id will display information about a submitted job which has not ended yet. Example: 
qstat -f 5525.mesu0

Job Id: 5525.mesu0
    Job_Name = jobMD2
    Job_Owner = karami@mesu1.dsi.upmc.fr
    resources_used.cpupercent = 6168
    resources_used.cput = 107:12:46
    resources_used.mem = 360012kb
    resources_used.ncpus = 64
    resources_used.vmem = 3613996kb
    resources_used.walltime = 01:44:06
    job_state = R
    queue = f64c
    server = mesu0
    Checkpoint = u
    ctime = Wed Jan 15 15:44:18 2014
    depend = beforeany:5526.mesu0@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr
    Error_Path = mesu1.dsi.upmc.fr:/home/karami/MDtools/NAMD/NAMD_2.9_Linux-x86
        _64-multicore/res0/jobMD2.e5525
    exec_host = mesu-uv/0*0
    exec_vnode = (mesu-uv[0]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[1]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[2]:ncpus=8+mesu
        -uv[3]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[4]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[5]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[6]:ncpus=8
        +mesu-uv[7]:ncpus=8)
    Hold_Types = n
    Join_Path = n
    Keep_Files = n
    Mail_Points = a
    mtime = Wed Jan 15 15:44:19 2014
    Output_Path = mesu1.dsi.upmc.fr:/home/karami/MDtools/NAMD/NAMD_2.9_Linux-x8
        6_64-multicore/res0/jobMD2.o5525
    Priority = 0
    qtime = Wed Jan 15 15:44:18 2014
    Rerunable = True
    Resource_List.mem = 991gb
    Resource_List.ncpus = 64
    Resource_List.nodect = 1
    Resource_List.place = free
    Resource_List.select = 1:ncpus=64
    Resource_List.walltime = 04:00:00
    stime = Wed Jan 15 15:44:18 2014
    session_id = 354237
    jobdir = /home/karami
    substate = 42
    Variable_List = PBS_O_SYSTEM=Linux,PBS_O_SHELL=/bin/bash,
        PBS_O_HOME=/home/karami,PBS_O_LOGNAME=karami,
        PBS_O_WORKDIR=/home/karami/MDtools/NAMD/NAMD_2.9_Linux-x86_64-multicor
        e/res0,PBS_O_LANG=en_US.UTF-8,
        PBS_O_PATH=/home/karami/amber12/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/
        bin/X11:/usr/X11R6/bin:/usr/games:/usr/lib64/jvm/jre/bin:/usr/lib/mit/b
        in:/usr/lib/mit/sbin:/opt/sgi/sgimc/bin:/opt/pbs/default/bin:/opt/pbs/d
        efault/sbin:/opt/intel/flexlm:/opt/dev/intel/eclipse:/home/karami/openm
        pi/bin,PBS_O_MAIL=/var/mail/karami,PBS_O_QUEUE=f64c,
        PBS_O_HOST=mesu1.dsi.upmc.fr
    comment = Job run at Wed Jan 15 at 15:44 on (mesu-uv[0]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[1]:
        ncpus=8+mesu-uv[2]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[3]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[4]:ncpus=8+mesu-u
        v[5]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[6]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[7]:ncpus=8)
    alt_id = cpuset=/PBSPro/5525.mesu0
    etime = Wed Jan 15 15:44:18 2014
    Submit_arguments = -q f64c -l Select=1:ncpus=64 -l walltime=04:00:00 jobMD2

    pset = iruhalf=r001i01b
    project = _pbs_project_default

Information about a finished job

qstat -fx job_id will display information about a finished job ( up to 14 days back).

PBS log messages

tracejob job_id will print log messages for a job. Example: 
tracejob 5525.mesu0

Job: 5525.mesu0

01/15/2014 15:44:18  L    Considering job to run
01/15/2014 15:44:18  S    Job Queued at request of karami@mesu1.dsi.upmc.fr, owner = karami@mesu1.dsi.upmc.fr, job name = jobMD2, queue = f64c
01/15/2014 15:44:18  S    Job Modified at request of Scheduler@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr
01/15/2014 15:44:18  S    Job Run at request of Scheduler@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr on exec_vnode
                          (mesu-uv[0]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[1]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[2]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[3]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[4]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[5]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[6]:ncpus=8+mesu-uv[7]:ncpus=8)
01/15/2014 15:44:18  S    Job Modified at request of Scheduler@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr
01/15/2014 15:44:18  L    Job run
01/15/2014 15:44:18  M    Resource_List.place = free
01/15/2014 15:44:18  M    created cpuset /PBSPro/5525.mesu0
01/15/2014 15:44:18  S    enqueuing into f64c, state 1 hop 1
01/15/2014 15:44:18  M    new_cpuset:  setting altid to CPU set named /PBSPro/5525.mesu0
01/15/2014 15:44:18  S    update from Mom without session id
01/15/2014 15:44:19  M    Started, pid = 354237

Computing nodes information

nodelist job_id : print list of nodes dedicated to the job_id. Example: 
nodelist 5525.mesu0

mesu-uv[0] mesu-uv[1] mesu-uv[2] mesu-uv[3] mesu-uv[4] mesu-uv[5] mesu-uv[6] mesu-uv[7] 
0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
During your job execution, your user_id is allowed to access the UV2000 in interactive mode. Use command : ssh uv . So you can follow in interaction mode your job. The following commands only work on MeSU-alpha (SGI UV 2000) nodeinfo: tool to monitor Linux node memory statistics, scrol with + / - Example: 
nodeinfo

Memory Statistics  Wed Jan 15 16:25:38 2014
mesu-uv
      ------------------------- Per Node KB --------------------------------  ------ Preferred Alloc -------  -- Loc/Rem ---
node       Total        Free        Used       Dirty        Anon        Slab     hit    miss foreign interlv   local  remote
   0   129982364   127278704     2703660         328       85224       60364    1128       0       0       0    1128       0
   1   130007040   127704740     2302300         332       59228       20068     564       0       0       0     564       0
   2   130007040   127710300     2296740         328       67192       21836    2256       0       0       0    2256       0
...
  30   130007040   127876496     2130544           0           0       19396       0       0       0       0       0       0
 TOT 16640876444 16369719680   271156764        2672     1483168     2451200   13536       0       0       0   13536       0
nodedist $(nodelist job_id): gives the distance between the nodes dedicated to a PBS job_id Example: 
nodelist 5525.mesu0

mesu-uv[0] mesu-uv[1] mesu-uv[2] mesu-uv[3] mesu-uv[4] mesu-uv[5] mesu-uv[6] mesu-uv[7] 
0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 

nodedist $(nodelist 5525.mesu0)

mesu-uv[0] mesu-uv[1] mesu-uv[2] mesu-uv[3] mesu-uv[4] mesu-uv[5] mesu-uv[6] mesu-uv[7] 
node list 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 7
  nd   0   1   2   3   4   5   6   7

   3 65 65 50 10 65 65 65 65
   4 65 65 65 65 10 50 65 65

item.title: PBS cheatsheet and script templates
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
Commands and scripts cheat sheet

Contents

  • 1 Connection / File transfers
    • 1.1 Connection
    • 1.2 SFTP transfer
    • 1.3 SSH transfer
    • 1.4 Internet to MeSU
  • 2 Working with modules
  • 3 Creating a PBS script
  • 4 Submitting a job
    • 4.1 On MeSU-alpha (SGI UV 2000)
    • 4.2 On MeSU-beta (SGI ICE XA)
  • 5 Monitoring
    • 5.1 Global monitoring
    • 5.2 Specific job monitoring
    • 5.3 Job array monitoring

Connection / File transfers

Connection

ssh loginLDAP@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr
ssh -X loginLDAP@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr
logout

SFTP transfer

sftp mesu.dsi.upmc.fr
sftp> pwd
sftp> cd subdirectory
sftp> lpwd

sftp> get path/to/mesufile
sftp> get path/to/mesufile path/to/newlocalfile

sftp> put localfile
sftp> put -r subdirectory

sftp> exit

SSH transfer

 scp filename userLDAP@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/

 scp file1 file2 file3 userLDAP@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/
 scp *.txt userLDAP@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:~subdirectory/
 scp -r local_subdirectory/ userLDAP@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/

 scp userLDAP@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/filename .
 scp userLDAP@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:~/subdirectory/\*.txt  .

Internet to MeSU

 wget https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/archive/master.zip

Working with modules

module avail
module load modules_names
module list
module unload module_name
module purge
module display module_name

Creating a PBS script

#!/bin/bash
#

#PBS -l select=1:ncpus=64
#PBS -l select=8:ncpus=8
#PBS -l select=3:ncpus=24
#PBS -l select=3:ncpus=24:mpiprocs=24

#PBS -l walltime=4:00:00
#PBS -N test
#PBS -j oe 

. /usr/share/modules/init/sh
module load module1
module load module2

# go to directory in which the job_script_file reside
cd $PBS_O_WORKDIR
time -p test_executable > log.txt

Submitting a job

On MeSU-alpha (SGI UV 2000)

qsub -q quv   myScript.sh
qsub -q f16c  myScript.sh
qsub -q quv   -l select=1:ncpus=64

On MeSU-beta (SGI ICE XA)

qsub -q qice  myScript.sh
qsub -q f336c myScript.sh
qsub -q qice  -l select=1:ncpus=24
qsub -q qice  -l select=4:ncpus=24

Monitoring

Global monitoring

qstat
qstat -u userName
qstat -T

Specific job monitoring

qstat -f job_id
tracejob job_id
nodelist job_id
nodedist $(nodelist job_id)
nodeinfo

Job array monitoring

qstat -tr

item.title: Tips and tricks
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
Do

Test on a small scale first Implement checkpointing Give reasonable wall times

Don’t

Request more than needed: you will wait longer than expected and use more credits Cancel jobs unnecessarily: Priority increases over time

item.title: MeSU-alpha
item.dc:creator: iscdadm
item.content:encoded:
Overview

MeSU-alpha is a SGI UV2000 server (SGI presentation), which has the particularity of being a SMP machine. In other words, it differs from a classical cluster architecture in the sense that it can act as a large shared memory system, with a total of 16TB of RAM memory, associated with 1024 cores.  

Hardware specifications

 

Compute nodes

MeSU-alpha is equipped with 64 computes blades, each of which made of 2 motherboards (or nodes), equipped with one Intel Xeon (Sandy Bridge) of 8 cores and with a local memory of 128Gb. The nodes are connected by a Numalink system (version 6) developed by SGI, which allows for the large shared memory.
Performance 19.05 TFlop/s
Processor Intel Xeon E5-4650L (Sandy Bridge) 2.6 GHz (2.7 with turbo); 8 cores
Memory 16TB DDR3 1600Mhz
Interconnection Numalink 6 12.5 Gb/s
Storage 90 TB (Raid 6) : 60x2TB SAS 7krpm

Front-end / login nodes

2 front-end servers, also called login nodes, allow users to install, compile and launch their jobs on the UV 2000 server. Each server is equipped with 2 Intel Xeon (Sandy Bridge) with 8 cores, 128 GB of ram memory and 600GB of hard drive storage.
Processors Intel Xeon E5-2670 (Sandy Bridge) 2.6 GHz (2.7 with turbo); 8 cores
Memory 128GB DDR3 1600 MHz (8 GB/cores)
Storage 2x300 GB SAS 15krpm (RAID 1)

Management server

A last server, called the management server, allows the system administrator to manage MeSU-alpha resources and perform maintenance operations. This server is equipped with 2 Intel Xeon (Sandy Bridge) with 4 cores each, 32 GB of ram memory and 1TB of hard drive storage.
Processors Intel Xeon E5-2609 (Sandy Bridge) 2.4 GHz; 4 cores
Memory 32GB DDR3 1600 MHz
Storage 2x500 GB SAS 15krpm (RAID 1)

 

Operating System / related software

SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES 12 SP2) is installed on MeSU-alpha, with the following associated software suite (other software are of course available) :
SGI System Management node 1.6, SGI Foundation Software 2.7 Suite of technical support tools and utilities that enable SGI systems to run at improved performance.
SGI Performance Suite 1.5, SGI Accelerate 1.5 Designed to accelerate the performance of applications on SGI systems utilizing Intel or AMD x86-64 processors.
SGI MPI 1.5 Focuses on features that accelerate applications, enable development of parallel and real-time applications, and manage system resources.
Intel Cluster Studio 2013 2014 2015 Integrated tool suite for HPC development.
Altair PBSPro 12.1.0 HPC workload management and job scheduling solution.

item.title: MeSU-beta
item.dc:creator: iscdadm
item.content:encoded:
Overview

MeSU-beta is a SGI ICE-XA server (SGI presentation), which has the particularity of being a distributed cluster. It is made of 3012 high performance computing cores, distributed in 144 nodes of 24 cores, and is associated with a fast storage system based on a Lustre filesystem. MeSU-beta also has the particularity of being an extremly energy efficient server, and is equipped with a warm-water cooling distribution unit (CDU), capable of cooling up to 305 kW.

Hardware specifications

Compute nodes

MeSU-alpha is equipped with 144 computes blades, each of which made of one motherboard (or node), equipped with two Intel Xeon (Sandy Bridge) of 12 cores each, and with a local memory of 128Gb. The nodes are connected by an Infiniband system, which allows for fast communication between them.

Performance 59.3 TFlop/s
Processor Intel Xeon E5-2670v3 2.3 GHz (12-cores)
Memory 128 Gb memory DDR4 2133MHz per node
Interconnection InfiniBand FDR switch
Storage 170 Tb.

 

Front-end / login node

1 front-end server, also called login node, allow users to install, compile and launch their jobs on the ICE XA server.
This server is equipped with 1 Intel Xeon (Sandy Bridge) with 12 cores, 128 GB of ram memory and 600GB of hard drive storage.

Processor Intel Xeon E5-2620v3 2.4 GHz (12-cores)
Memory  128 Gb memory DDR4 RDIMMs ECC 2133 MHz
Storage 2x300 GB SAS 15krpm (RAID 1)

 

Rack leader and admin node

This server, called the management server, allows the system administrator to manage MeSU-beta resources, perform maintenance operations and hosts the software images for the compute nodes..
It is equipped with 2 Intel Xeon (Sandy Bridge) with 6 cores each, 62 GB of ram memory and 2TB of hard drive storage.

Processors bi-processor Intel Xeon E5-2603v3 1.6 GHz, (6-cores)
Memory 64 Gb memory DDR4 RDIMMs ECC 2133 MHz
Storage 2 disks SATA 1 Tb 7,200 rpm

 

Operating System / related software

SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES 12 SP2) is installed on MeSU-beta, with the following associated software suite (other software are of course available) :

SGI System Management node 1.6, SGI Foundation Software 2.7 Suite of technical support tools and utilities that enable SGI systems to run at improved performance.
SGI Performance Suite 1.5, SGI Accelerate 1.5 Designed to accelerate the performance of applications on SGI systems utilizing Intel or AMD x86-64 processors.
SGI MPI 1.5 Focuses on features that accelerate applications, enable development of parallel and real-time applications, and manage system resources.
Intel Cluster Studio 2013 2014 2015 Integrated tool suite for HPC development.
Altair PBSPro 12.1.0 HPC workload management and job scheduling solution.

item.title: Visualization room
item.dc:creator: iscdadm
item.content:encoded:
Centre for data visualisation

Designed in collaboration with an architect (V. Taurisson), the centre for Data Visualisation (CDV) is part of the ISCD’s research and training centre. The centre is committed to improving the understanding of science by developing innovative algorithms to visualisation data. The centre provides an exciting, state-of-the-art environment for visualization and data analysis with a wide stereoscopic projection system. These unique facilities are available for use to all faculty, graduate students and partners. In addition, faculty and students enjoy an interactive and collaborative environment through the CDV seminar series, invited speakers, workshops, and summer schools programs.  

Missions

The missions of CDV include, but are not restricted to:
  • serving as a central point of access to advanced visualisation technology
  • assembling research teams to pursue interdisciplinary research on data visualisation and analysis techniques
  • developing custom visualisation solutions for our academic or industrial partners.
The center is also involved in a research program in fundamental visualization and visual analytics with several faculty members working on these topics.

Resources and support

  ViSU staff provide support and assistance to users. It also provides consulting on how to utilize the resources efficiently and training for users of these resources (see Training catalog). We are looking for projects to take advantage of this unique technology, for teaching, training and research purposes. For further information, contact us at contact_iscd@upmc.fr

item.title: Getting started
item.dc:creator: norgeot
item.content:encoded:
Getting started

This guide is dedicated to the usage of MeSU-alpha and MeSU-beta computing servers, and should help you to get a better understanding of the machines you are going to use, and provide you with enough elements to run your first jobs. Make sure to fully understand the first sections content, in order to be able to follow the walkthrough in the "try it yourself" section. A note on parallel computing: Newcomers unfamiliar with the basis of parallel computing are invited to consult the excellent LLNL tutorial on the subject, as well as an explanation of the differences between the two main programming methods used in parallel computing: OpenMP & MPI.

1 - System Overview

  The global HPCaVe servers architecture is more complex than a personal computer. They are made of two kinds of nodes (a node represents a subset of a server, dedicated to specific tasks) - login nodes and computing nodes - which communicate together via a specific program called a batch scheduler.  
1.1 - Login nodes
In order to run a program on one of our two computing servers (MeSU alpha and MeSU beta), you will have to first log into the login nodes. Login nodes are dedicated and separate small servers which act as a secure gateway between your computer and the computing nodes, on which your program will be running. Note: login nodes are not meant for heavy computation, and any intensive job running on them will be automatically killed. The login nodes are dedicated to the following tasks:
  • Transferring files from/to your personal computer.
  • Compiling your source code
  • Setting up your jobs' parameters and variables
  • Monitoring the execution of your jobs
 
1.2 - Computing nodes (on MeSU alpha and MeSU beta)
Computing nodes constitute the core of the computing system. At HPCaVe, the computing nodes are distributed on two machines: MeSU alpha and MeSU beta. Your jobs will run on those nodes, and will be submitted, managed and monitored with the batch scheduler.  
1.3 - Data directories
Different filesystems are mounted on MeSU servers. When logged in, you have a direct access to your /home directory, which is meant to host your codes, programs, and allow you to submit jobs. This directory is not meant for data storage, and is limited to 30Gb per user. Other directories are to be used for data storage:
  • /scratchalpha/username: Data directory, optimized for MeSU-alpha usage (250 Gb per user)
  • /scratchbeta/username: Data directory, optimized for MeSU-beta usage (500 Gb per user)
Note: data located on /scratchalpha is only accessible from MeSU-alpha, and data on /scratchbeta from MeSU-beta.
1.4 - The batch scheduler
A batch scheduler is a very specific software managing all users' jobs submissions, in order to prioritize and allocate resources for every of them. Acting as a gateway between the login nodes and the computing nodes, its role is to optimize the cluster utilization according to the stack of pending jobs, and their requested resources (execution time, number of CPUs, maximum memory...). The batch scheduler used on HPCaVe servers is called PBS.

2 - Connection to HPCave servers

  If you did not already opened an account, please consult the dedicated page. In order to launch your first jobs, you will first need to login to the login nodes, using the Secure Shell communication protocol (ssh), which guarantees a secure transfer of data. You can either use ssh via a command line interface (CLI) or a graphical application. To connect, type in the terminal (make sure to replace "your-username" with your real username) :
[crayon lang=shell]ssh your-username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr[/crayon]
or use the X11 session forwarding if you want to have access to the GUI (Graphical User Interface) of the softwares you are using:
[crayon lang=shell]ssh -Y your-username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr[/crayon]
After typing in your password, you should be welcomed with a message provided by the system administrator, which will give you information about the current status of MeSU and future maintenance operations:      

3 - Uploading files from your computer (and back!)

  In order to upload files to MeSU servers, you will either need to use a specialized FTP software such as Filezilla, or use terminal UNIX commands such as scp, rsync, fputs... Please note that the servers are connected to internet, and you can therefore also download items with the command wget for instance, or by checking out a git, svn or mercurial repository:
[crayon lang=shell] wget https://www.domain.com/archive.tar.gz svn checkout https://www.domain.com/path/to/svn/repo git clone https://www.domain.com/path/to/git/repo hg clone https://www.domain.com/path/to/mercurial/repo [/crayon]
 
3.1 - Filezilla (Windows, MacOsX and linux)
  Filezilla is one of the most popular FTP (File Transfer Protocol) software available, and allows for an easy transfer of data between two network machines. On the following screenshot, please fill the fields of the zone 2 as follows:
  • Host: sftp://mesu.dsi.upmc.fr
  • Username: Your HPCaVe username
  • Password
  • Port: 22 is the standard port for ssh protocol
Once you are done, hit the Quickconnect button, and transfer files between the zone 4 (your local computer) and the zone 5 (HPCaVe servers).    
3.2 - scp (linux & MacOsX)
  On a linux or MacOSX system (and through MobaXTerm for instance for Windows users), to transfer a source file called main.cpp to your session on HPCaVe servers:
[crayon lang=shell]scp /local/path/to/main.cpp your-username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:/path/on/HPCaVE/[/crayon]
The scp command also supports wildcards (*) selection and directory copying:
[crayon lang=shell] scp *.txt your-username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:/path/on/HPCaVE/ scp -r directory/ your-username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:/path/on/HPCaVE/ [/crayon]
In order to copy a file back from HPCaVe servers to your personal computer, you will first have to retrieve your local IP adress:
  • "ifconfig" in a terminal in linux
  • Apple Menu > System preferences > Network on MacOSX
then, while logged in to HPCaVe login nodes, type in a terminal ("user" is the username on your personal computer):
[crayon lang=shell] scp /path/to/file.txt user@your-IP-adress:/path/on/your/computer/ [/crayon]
   

4 - Running a job

  You will mainly use HPCaVe servers to run two very distinct types of programs:
  1. Already installed softwares.
  2. Softwares of which you have the source code (on your computer, or through a remote source control system), and need to install (compile).
Although the main linux utilities and compilers (grep, cat, gcc...) are available in your environment as soon as you connect to HPCaVe servers, not all functionalities and software are accessible by default. If you wish to use a specific scientific software (Matlab, gromacs, freefem++ ...) or a certain suite of developing tools (mkl, intel Vtunes, specific compiler versions...), you will have to use modules.  
4.1 - A note on "modules" (working with an installed software)
Modules act as software packages which you can load interactively in order to gain access to their contents. They are used to avoid conflicts between software and libraries versions, and to provide you at all time with a clean working environment ( for instance no environment variables, defining the location of software on the servers, should have the same name but point to different paths). In order to know which modules are available and see if you need to use them, you can either consult the dedicated page or type the command:
[crayon lang=shell]module avail[/crayon]
To load a module and gain access to its content, type:
[crayon lang=shell]module load name-of-the-module[/crayon]
The specific program or software should now be available at the command line.  
4.2 - Compiling your code
If you have access to the source code of an external software, or if you developed your own code, you will most probably be able to compile and run it on HPCaVe servers. Compiling a code (transforming the source code in a binary executable file) is a whole topic by itself, but many tools are available on HPCaVe servers in regards with code development, for instance:
  • Collection of open source compilers (gcc, gfortan, mpifortran, mpic++, mpicc...) in recent and older versions
  • Extensive collection of scientific libraries
  • Optimized versions of MPI and OpenMP for the HPCaVe servers
  • Intel compilers and scientific libraries such as mkl
  • Profiling and debugging tools (gdb, gprof, valgrind, Intel VTunes...)
  • Text editors (vi, vim, GNU Emacs, nano)
Note: If you did not load the correct modules before compiling your code, your compiler should output error messages specifying the missing libraries.  
4.3 - Set up your job script
As explained in the Overview section, the communication between the login nodes and the compute nodes is managed by PBS, to which you will request computing resources, specify your job parameters and commands to execute through a shell or python file, called a PBS script. Whether you wish to work with an existing software or with a compiled program, you will therefore have to write such a file.
Minimal script example
[crayon lang=shell] #!/bin/bash #Request 64 CPU cores on one node (typical for MeSU-alpha) #PBS -l select=1:ncpus=64 #The command below allows  "module" to properly initialize a bash / sh shell in non-interactive mode. It sources the file for the chosen shell, #In the example, "sh". It can be bash or tcsh as well. . /etc/profile.d/module.sh #Load the mpt module, to gain access to an optimized OpenMP version module load mpt/2.16 #Copy the executable to the temporary directory (not necessary for existing softwares) #the variable $PBS_O_WORKDIR designs the path from which the qsub command will be executed cp $PBS_O_WORKDIR/myProgram . #Environment variables export OMP_NUM_THREADS=64 #./myProgram could here be a compiled executable file ./myProgram > log.txt #Transfer log file from the compute nodes to the user directory cp log.txt $PBS_O_WORKDIR [/crayon]
Explanation
Note that although the line starting with a "#" will be parsed as comments, the first few lines of the file will allow you to specify different resources. For instance, to request 32 cores on MeSU alpha, you should replace the line 3 with:
[crayon lang=shell] #PBS -l select=1:ncpus=32 [/crayon]
To request 96 cores distributed on MeSU beta, you should actually request to use 4 nodes (see MeSU-beta technical specifications) containing each 24 cores:
[crayon lang=shell] #PBS -l select=4:ncpus=24 [/crayon]
If your job should run for 16 hours (more than the 8 hours allowed by default), add the line:
[crayon lang=shell] #PBS -l walltime=16:00:00 [/crayon]  
NB: Be aware that your program will run in a temporary directory on the compute nodes, which won't be accessible anymore at the end of the execution. You must therefore transfer any output data back to your working environment ($PBS_O_WORKDIR) on the login nodes (line 11).  
4.4 - Submit a job
Once the PBS script has been correctly set up, requesting your job to run on the compute nodes is then as simple as executing the qsub command:
[crayon lang=shell] qsub your_PBS_script.sh [/crayon]
which will output on success a unique string, the job identifier (referred to later as jobID), in the form "123456.mesu0" which will be useful to get information on your job status. If not specified, PBS will try to send your job to MeSU-alpha or MeSU-beta depending on the resources requested. If you know which server you want to run on, you can submit your job with one of the following commands:
[crayon lang=shell] qsub -qalpha  yourScript.sh # To run on MeSU-alpha (UV2000) qsub -qbeta yourScript.sh # To run on MeSU-beta (ICE XA) [/crayon]
   

5 - Checking your job status

  The jobs you will submit to PBS do not usually run as soon as you have ran the command qsub. Indeed, PBS first has to parse your script file in order to insert your job in the queue system. Depending on the resources (number of nodes and CPU cores, maximum memory, walltime i.e. maximum time of your job) you have requested in the header of your PBS script, the batch scheduler will put your job in an appropriate waiting queue. You can obtain information about the status of all jobs by typing one of the following commands:
[crayon lang=shell] qstat # to list all jobs qstat -u your-username # to get information about your jobs [/crayon]
In particular, the qstat command should tell you if your job is waiting to run (Q), running (R), on hold (H) or finishing (E). If your job does not appear in the output of qstat, it might either have already been processed, or have failed because of a wrong PBS script. You could then run the tracejob command in order to have information on your job status:
[crayon lang=shell] tracejob 123456.mesu0 01/15/2014 15:44:18 L Considering job to run 01/15/2014 15:44:18 S Job Queued at request of user@mesu1.dsi.upmc.fr, owner = user@mesu1.dsi.upmc.fr, job name = myJob, queue = f64c 01/15/2014 15:44:18 S Job Run at request of Scheduler@mesu0.dsi.upmc.fr on exec_vnode (mesu-uv[0]:ncpus=8+ ... +mesu-uv[7]:ncpus=8) ... 01/15/2014 15:44:18 L Job run 01/15/2014 15:44:18 S enqueuing into f64c, state 1 hop 1 01/15/2014 15:44:19 M Started, pid = 354237 [/crayon]
Once your job has finished running (or crashed), a log file ending in .o + jobID should be written in the directory from which you submitted your job with qsub, for instance myJob.o123456. Finally, the command qstat can be used with specific options to get more details about a finished job:
[crayon lang=shell] qstat -fx 123456.mesu0 Job Id: 123456.mesu0 Job_Name = jobMD2 Job_Owner = user@mesu1.dsi.upmc.fr resources_used.cpupercent = 6168 #Percentage of CPU resources used (here 6168%, around 62 cores at full efficiency) resources_used.cput = 107:12:46 #Total CPU time consumed resources_used.mem = 360012kb #memory used resources_used.ncpus = 64 #Number of CPU cores used resources_used.vmem = 3613996kb #Virtual memory used resources_used.walltime = 01:44:06 #walltime used (or "clock-time") ... Resource_List.mem = 991gb # Available memory Resource_List.ncpus = 64 #Available number of cores Resource_List.nodect = 1 #Number of nodes (1 on MeSU-alpha) Resource_List.place = free #Placement options Resource_List.select = 1:ncpus=64 #Submission options from the PBS script Resource_List.walltime = 04:00:00 #Walltime requested ... [/crayon]
 

6 - Try it yourself!

  You should now be able to run your first computing jobs!
  • To follow the example showing you how to compile and run a program from source code, download and extract the corresponding zip archive.
  • If you wish to use your own code, try to replicate the steps in 6.1 - Using a dummy parallel C code, or if you want to try using an existing software, refer yourself to 6.2 - Running an existing software.
 
6.0 - Common part
 
  1. First, connect to HPCaVe and create a directory to host your test codes, data and outputs. If you are using Windows, you can use a graphical client such as MobaXTerm for this purpose. On linux and MacOSX, type in a terminal:
    [crayon lang=shell] ssh username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr mkdir hpcaveTest logout # to quit the ssh session [/crayon]
    Note that you can either logout with the logout command, or by typing ctrl + D.
  2. Transfer necessary files from your computer to HPCaVe servers. Windows users can use Filezilla for instance to copy the archive source code and scripts, while linux and MacOSX users can type in a terminal:
    [crayon lang=shell] scp -r /path/to/wiki/* username@mesu.dsi.upmc.fr:~/hpcaveTest [/crayon]
  3. You can now connect back to HPCaVe servers, and check that your files have properly been copied to the hpcaveTest directory.
 
6.1 - Using a dummy parallel C code (using OpenMP on MeSU-alpha)
In this section, we are going to compile and run a dummy OpenMP parallel code on MeSU-alpha, which will approximate the value of pi in parallel according to the Monte Carlo method. Once the source code has been transfered to HPCaVe servers, navigate to the wiki/openmp directory, and first compile the source code with gcc, enabling the fopenmp flag to enable OpenMP support:
[crayon lang=shell] gcc pi_openmp.c -o pi_openmp -fopenmp [/crayon]
You should now have an executable file, called pi_openmp, which we will submit to PBS through the script file called script_openmp.sh:
[crayon lang=shell] #!/bin/bash #PBS -l select=1:ncpus=16 #PBS -l walltime=04:00:00 #Load modules . /usr/share/modules/init/sh module load mpt/2.11 #Copy the executable to the temporary directory cp $PBS_O_WORKDIR/pi_openmp . #Execute omplace -nt 16 ./pi_openmp > log.txt #Transfer log cp log.txt $PBS_O_WORKDIR [/crayon]
In order to launch the job on MeSU-alpha, you will have to run the command:
[crayon lang=shell] qsub -qalpha script_openmp.sh [/crayon]
If the servers are not fully loaded, your job should run quite quickly, but remember that you can still check its execution status with qstat and qstat -fx jobID. Once your job has been processed, a file called log.txt should have been written in the directory wiki/openmp, containing the result of your computation (the approximation of pi), as well as information on the time spent running. Feel free to experiment and change the submission parameters or pieces of the code, as well as running on MeSU-beta instead of MeSU-alpha (qsub -qbeta). Note: Other samples are provided in the archive, to have a quick preview of working with MPI and hybrid MPI/OpenMP. Keep in mind that when using mpi, you will have to compile your code with an adapted compiler such as mpicc, and run it with mpirun or mpiexec in the PBS script:
[crayon lang=shell] mpicc pi_mpi.c -o pi_mpi mpirun -n 16 ./pi_mpi [/crayon]
6.2 - Running an existing software (Work In Progress)
The workflow to run an existing software (gromacs in this example) is simpler than compiling and running your own source code. After having transfered your data, you should just have to create an appropriate PBS script file containing the commands allowing you to run the software. For instance, to run gromacs on 48 cores of MeSU-beta and on data contained in the /work directory:
[crayon lang=shell] #!/bin/bash #PBS -l select=2:ncpus=24 #PBS -l walltime=04:00:00 . /usr/share/modules/init/sh module load gromacs gromacs -i /work/username/myData.bin -n 48 cp output $PBS_O_WORKDIR [/crayon]
And finally, to submit your script file to PBS:
[crayon lang=shell] qsub -qbeta myScript.sh [/crayon]
At the end of the execution (checked with qstat), you should have some new data in the /work/user directory, and some information on your job in the log.txt file.
